transcript.title: Toyota Manufacturing, Kentucky, Inc. v. Williams

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now in Number oh oh ten eighty-nine, Toyota Motor Manufacturing versus Ella Williams.
Mr. Roberts.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mister Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

The Sixth Circuit below held that the respondent, Ms. Williams, was substantially limited in performing manual tasks and therefore disabled under the Americans with Disabilities Act because she could not perform the manual tasks associated with her assembly line job, specifically gripping a sponge and repetitively wiping down cars with her arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time.
That test for disability status was wrong.
It was wrong because it is inconsistent with the statute which requires a substantial limitation on a major life activity.

Repetitively wiping down cars with arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time is not a major life activity, and being limited in that activity does not constitute being substantially limited in the major life activity of performing manual tasks in general.
A plaintiff must show a substantial limitation in a broad range of manual tasks to meet the statutory standard.

The most that the court of appeals could extrapolate was that Ms. Williams was substantially limited in the tasks associated with jobs that required gripping tools and repetitive activity with arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time.
That is a specialized and idiosyncratic limitation.
It is not a substantial...

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: limitation...
Mr. Roberts,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: can I just ask if at at the outset, so you have plenty of time to comment on there's expert testimony, as I read the briefs, that on your opponent's side that she's suffers a lack of access to the labor market from fifty to fifty-five percent of the jobs, both nationwide and in Kentucky.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: A a number of things about that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: When you say it was rejected by the district court, you don't mean it was inadmissible.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The the district court considered it and said it was not probative of what it purported to show, a loss of access to the job market.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, in the same vein as Justice Stevens' question, how does the worker's compensation notion of disability fit in? As I understand it, she was assessed as having a twenty percent what was it partial disability for worker's compensation purposes.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: B- but but pursuant to very different standards.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why wouldn't twenty percent limitation twenty percent occupational impairment be a substantial limitation?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, first of all, it may be pertinent if the standards were the same, but only under the working category.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why why did the court of appeals avoid addressing the work approach? It was it because it thought this Court had rejected that?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, a couple of reasons.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Should we address that, or because it was not addressed below, leave that alone?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I think the the more typical approach would be not to address the major life activity of working since it was not addressed below, except to this extent.
The test is circular.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well in in looking at a substantial limitation, do we focus on the things that the person cannot do or the things they still can do or both?
What do we do?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: C- Certainly with respect to manual tasks, you have to look at both because it's not enough, obviously, to say there's one particular manual task that I can't do.
She...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Roberts, may I just stop you on something you just said? I thought the Sixth Circuit said in its opinion that it had considered recreation, household chores, living generally, as well as the work-related impairments.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: A a very important sentence that I think has to be read carefully.
That's  You can...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assume that, though, in some cases, couldn't you?
I mean  it...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're not you do- if suppose a person says I cannot be a watchmaker and the reason he can't is he's blind.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Certainly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even though he only mentioned watchmaking.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Certainly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it's it's really the disability that we're focusing on, and in the circumstances someone like that would be able not only not to perform the job but also not to do the things that the judge said below, a reasonable inference from the nature of the disability.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: First, because that type of an inference is contradicted by the record.
activity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's what I w- w- my until you said the last part, my thought was, well, we need a trial on this.
Oh, no because...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: serious is this disability? What d- is does it disqualify her from doing? But do we have to go on to categorize between whether it's working, gardening, what is a major life activity? I mean, isn't it just is this person hurt badly enough that there are an awful lot of things that she can't do?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.
And both...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's bothering me.
this or that or the other thing,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: or to use a more broad, general judgment, is this person incapable of doing a lot of things that people do in life.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, first of all, with respect to working, it is important I think to identify what major life activity you're talking about because as the EEOC has recognized in its regulations, as this Court has indicated, there are all sorts of problems when you say working is a major life activity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, can I just interrupt again? I you've explained why the fifty percent figure is is wrong.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Of yes, you can, and I and certainly in a manual tasks case, you can submit evidence and say, here's an example of manual tasks that I can't perform, the ones that are required at work.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did it is it is it your view that by including the non-work im- impairment that she has, you sort of increase the universe of things she has to she you compare it to, and therefore, the there's a smaller percentage of an impairment, and therefore, it's not substantial?
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is I'm limited in manual tasks, you do have to look, and this is what all the other courts of appeals have done, the broad range of manual tasks.
That's not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to particularly I suppose is the sentence of the court's opinion which says the fact that Williams can perform a range of isolated, non-repetitive manual tasks performed over a short period of time, such as tending to her personal hygiene or carrying out personal or household chores, does not affect a determination that her impairment substantially limits her ability cough> to perform the range of manual tasks associated with an assembly line job.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the criterion of whether she's sub- s- she's substantially limited.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's wrong.
do the assembly line...

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: job is enough for us.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, the nub of it is the th- th- the the limitation to considering one job IE an assembly line job.
With respect to working --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: overriding sin, that was it, wasn't it? Instead of considering a range of jobs I'm sorry a class of jobs...

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If if if they're going to look at it under manual tasks, you've got to look at all manual tasks.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you're going to look at it under working, you've got to look at either a class or a broad range of jobs.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I was going to say if if you're doing it under under under the major life activity of manual tasks, you wouldn't just look at jobs.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: just jobs.
courts have done...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I didn't mean to interrupt you.
under under manual tasks?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I would still need to know what about everyday activities.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but aren't at this point, aren't aren't we getting sort of academic about it? If somebody let's assume the category is manual tasks, but they identify a hundred jobs which she I me- I mean, a great range of things that she can't do.
I mean, at that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: point, you've made a pretty good prima facie case, haven't...
you?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the evidence then would probably not be that she can take care of herself generally.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The- then it would seem to me to be properly analyzed as a working case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Very well, Mr. Roberts.

Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: We agree that the Sixth Circuit applied an incorrect test in determining whether a person is substantially limited in the major life activity of performing manual tasks.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Ms. McDowell, I didn't think that the Sixth Circuit had said we're looking only at one job.
No, we don't think so, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: T- t- types.
That may be correct, Justice Ginsburg.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He refers to painting, plumbing, and roofing, et cetera.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I I suppose it's perfectly obvious a person who can't raise their hands above heart level couldn't paint the ceiling at least.
That may well be correct, Your Honor .
of the analysis, if one --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And most painters are not limited to just painting floors, I don't think.
That's correct.
the court of appeals...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: test do you you just look at the whole scope of jobs, or isn't it just limited to jobs that this person is has has some demonstrated capacity for or interest in? I mean, you know, what if I can't be a you know, a jet pilot? You know, I ha- I'm disabled from being a jet pilot.
No, it's not irrelevant, Justice Scalia.
and ability to perform.
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I didn't think so.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Un- under the Longshore Harbor Workers and Compensation Act , we ru- the courts routinely look at what jobs are in the community that this person is eligible for after they've suffered an injury.
in in these kinds of cases...
e- Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in looking at the manual task approach, how how is the fact finder supposed to decide which manual tasks are sufficiently important to constitute a substantial limitation? I mean, how do you weigh that? H- how do we decide it? Is there any guidance on that?
The courts of appeals thus far have looked at aside from the Sixth Circuit, of course, have looked to those manual tasks that are basic to everyday life.
on the major life activity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: question like substantial, certainly you would get to a jury question at some point, wouldn't you?
Oh, certainly it would become a jury question in many cases.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Conceptually it seems to work better your your way.
The EEOC regs that you're referring to discuss the major life activity of working.
Yes, that wrecks it. I know. I know, but they're...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: taking the wrong they're taking the wrong approach in your view.

I believe this route is consistent wit- with what the agency has said, specifically that one should consider working as a major life activity only if a plaintiff cannot satisfy any of the other major life activities, including performing manual tasks.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask you one question? Is it relevant that she may not be able to perform a lot of jobs she never performed? For example, is it relevant that she couldn't be a roofer, for example?
It may or may not, and I'm not sure that we have a position on that at this point, Justice Stevens.
The mere fact that she hadn't done it --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: her employment history and that's the only possible thing we look at in determining whether her working ability has been impaired.
No, I don't think you look only at the...
plaintiff's working history.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: then that she couldn't be a roofer, electrician, or a painter or a lot of other things.
It may bell [: well] well be relevant.
To what extent do we...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: take account of the particular individual? For example, for someone who is making a high income as a corporate executive, it wouldn't matter that she couldn't vacuum the rug because she's has paid someone else to do that for many years.
May I answer, Your Honor? In focusing on a major life activity of manual tasks, we would suggest looking at the generalized person.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: This case is not about the inability to perform a single job.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Rosenbaum, so far as the question presented here is, do you are you would defend the Sixth Circuit's opinion?
I defend the result, Mr. Chief Justice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But not the reasoning?
Not in its entirety, but part of it I do.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, where do you disagree?
I disagree when the Sixth Circuit says that after you determine an individual is substantially limited, you must go farther and that individual must show that their limitation affects their work.
the correct statute. Well, then I...
yes, sir, and I appreciated that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, do you think a f- a fair reading of the opinion of in the c- at the end of the carryover paragraph at four A, it says, it would appear, nevertheless, from the language of the act, the EEOC's interpretation of the Supreme Court analysis in Sutton, that in order to be disabled, the plaintiff must show that her manual disability involves a class of manual activities affecting the ability of to perform tasks at work.

text_blocks.text: So so, that's u- that's what I'd like to know how to deal with exactly.
And if so,

I think we are there.
We are there. Good.

It I would submit it's a question of substantiality always, that you're correct in stating that the degree of impairment and the definition of the major life activity are inevitably linked together in the analysis.
is. Well, what should...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: working is a major life activity?
It is my opinion that working is a major life activity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's a little hard to think of a disability that affects a broad range of employment tasks that doesn't affect other areas of life.
Well, of course.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: wait a minute, and as Justice Breyer said, the- these are evidentiary m- matters that go to a a a a larger point.
Well, that's why Ms. Williams...
Yes, th- that's why this Ms. Williams' case is a strong case.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

to find her disabled.

If it...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Otherwise you could have answered my question no.
You you --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: an individualized determination because the most severe case of carpal tunnel syndrome could qualify as rendering that person a disabled person within the meaning of this this specialized legislation.
That's right because the regulations say is that if they're significantly restricted concerning the condition, the manner, or the duration of the activity, then they are substantially disabled.
has trouble --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: have any notion of what percentage of the population would be taken in if we use the standard n- the class that she was put in for worker's compensation purposes, t- a twenty percent occupational impairment how many people?
I c- I have no figures that would relate that to the population as a whole.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there anything that suggests that those people, the people who are in a sense not the most disabled, but the people who are not quite in that category are the ones who are really discriminated against?
S-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Because the ones who can't work at all, obviously, are not discriminated against.

Well, I I'm not sure that I can explain all of its ramifications, but I can say that there was certainly a concern that people who were labeled disabled would be stereotyped and that employers would be hesitant to give them the same vocational opportunities as non-disabled people would be, even though the disability had no effect on the job.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well that one one of the problems with this is w- we're looking at the entry classification, disability, but on the facts of this case, she was able to do a job if the employer sliced it a certain way.
That issue is not reached in this case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I I know that we we don't get to what is the how much accommodation would be required, but it's a little hard to to keep th- that from view because if the employer doesn't have would not have to make the accommodation that she's seeking, the- then this case is not very significant.
Well, let me let let me say a couple of things.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But the the employer decided to change what the workers do, and as I un- understand assembly lines, that's not uncommon to take people from doing the same thing every day, day in and day out, train them for several jobs, and then they rotate.

In the Sixth Circuit, there's the case of Kiphart versus Saturn where that issue was put to the jury where the employer said, you've got to be able to rotate through all of the tasks in your group, and since you, the allegedly disabled person, were not able to, we're entitled to fire you.
but we say it wasn't.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: standard d- of accommodation, is it?
Excuse me?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I- isn't essential isn't the standard, is it, that the employer has to show that it's essential that...
No, no.
There are reasonableness considerations to accommodation.
these things.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: don't you have to look at both in in trying to assess the extent of somebody's incapacity to do a major life activity? You co- you...
inevitably...
it's not a defense to the ADA claim to say, look, they can do a lot of stuff.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Rosenbaum, co- could could you tell us what you want us to do? Assuming we agree with you, you want us to take the Sixth Circuit opinion as as be- as a as affirming a summary judgment for you on the disability portion.
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, let's assume we don't agree with you on on the point.
Not in total.
They --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's that's what they...
say. I'm pre-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: wondering why we can do that when the Sixth Circuit hasn't addressed the you know, the other areas of disability.
The case is before the Court in the procedural posture of proceedings for a summary judgment.
It goes to a jury.
It goes to the jury.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Rosenbaum.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, you have two minutes remaining.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What about the other the other two issues? I mean, the the the court of appeals did not purport to reach the working as a substantial life activity and what else? Lifting as a substantial life activity.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Can certainly reverse with respect to the summary judgment on performing manual tasks.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, you acknowledge we would have to remand for for its consideration of those.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Unless the Court felt, given the fact that the issues with respect to working were insinuated into the case by the Sixth Circuit's approach, that it was appropriate to address that major life activity as well.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even as to manual tasks, are you asking for a a ruling in your favor on summary judgment on that, or are you saying it shouldn't have been e- effectively summary judgment for the plaintiff and then we go to the next stage, that that it could be a jury question o- on manual tasks?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Roberts.
